comments.commentBody:
Vladimir, so over the top
this political polka must stop
either one job or t'other
but Comrade, dear brother
not both,the presumptuous closed shop.

I suspected that most Russians simply want a normal turnover of leaders like other countries that they neighbor such Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Ukraine.

The Putin Medvedev tandem appears contrived and manipulative.

Even in Russia, you cannot fool most of the people most of the time. This tandem worked for a while.

As long as the vote is secret and counted honestly, the people will show their will.

Missing from this article is any discussion of the state of putin's political opposition, his decade long effort to neuter it, and whether this dip in his poll numbers in any way threatens his reelection.
"meddling by western governments" that's pretty funny, as if western gov'ts don't have enough to meddle in keeping their own people relatively pacified.

Why does this sound familiar?

“When a regular person has to deal with financial problems or some other problems in his day-to-day life, when he faces corruption and other small problems, he doesn’t remember the massive problems” of the past. “The indignation that person has is usually turned against the current authority.”

If you stay long in politics, you can see how the voters sour from ongoing situation, It is not exception for Putin.

Given the fact that low caliber politicians as Merkel,Sarkozy and unremmebered name of British PM, Putin is still holding one virtue , that is he is in control. Europe extremely unexpectedly showed that nobody is controlling anything. 1990's Russia looks like todays europe.
this article is quite dense.  i dont understand just how it is that he is hurting himself if he has a 61 percent approval rating.  not well described at all.
Perhaps the Russians desire new blood.  But who better than Putin to keep the kleptocratic "oligarchs" at bay?

The Russian (Putin) government is so depressing.  Whereas the Chinese are criminally repressive they make no claims to democracy.  Russia claims democracy, a free press, an independent Duma, transparent legal system... But it is its own evil empire and very disheartening to watch.

So much ignorance about Putin. Gorbachev wasn't ruthless, so they got disorder. Yeltsin wasn't ruthless, so they got chaos. Putin is ruthless, so they got stability and capitalism firmly planted. No, not the kind we want -- a mix of America's Gilded Age and America's gangster era -- but permanent and evolving. This is no mean feat, considering that Russia never knew a civil society until the fall of the Soviets only a couple of decades ago.

And no, we don't like Russia's, i.e. Putin's, foreign policy -- it's too...well, too pro-Russian. So it's in our government's interest to let Putin's image be spun in the most unfavorable light.

As for Putin and KGB. Yeah, right, and what about a guy named George H. W. Bush, ex-director of CIA? Oh that's right, they're the good guys.

Is Putin a good guy? I think he's a patriot. And I think he's laying the foundation for stability that true democracy can be built on. You don't want a chaotic vacuum that despotism fills, then chaos again, so that despotism fills again. Once order is restored, institutions strengthened and civil life restored, then democracy. The French revolution was chaos, then The Terror, then chaos, then Napoleon, then chaos leading to Louis Napoleon. Russian Revolution, then democracy, then chaos, then Stalin. The Kaiser, then chaos, then democracy, then chaos, then Hitler. Franco was a fascist, yet he left an infrastructure that provided stability for Spain's transition to democracy. And even here, in God's country, government stability and popular democracy were firmly establish only after our perhaps most ruthless president, Andrew Jackson.

Putin is no tyrant, no dictator. He's authoritarian. Those who think Russia can govern itself now are totally clueless, though they don't lack for sanctimony. I think the Times is right, that it doesn't matter how good you are, after a while you grow stale. Sure, let's see Putin out and feel virtuous. Then what?

Oh the Brookings Institution and Hoover Institution and all that 'thinking'! A 16-year old kid at the 'Young Republican Club' in my local private school can do better Russia-bashing.

Real reform to help middle class Americans hasn't happened for the last 3 decades. Congress and Senate are run by lobbyists. Somehow, Russia needs lessons in democracy! If Russians are fed up with Putin, let them decide their fate, and let's work on deciding our own.

United Russia formed around Putin because the "silent majority" in Russia wanted stability more than they wanted freedom at the time. But now that Russia has become more stable, the pendulum is going to swing the other way.
He may just have to take power by force. At least then it would all be honest, without the smoke and mirrors of an "election".

Cry all you want, gone are the 90s of yelsint. Gorbachev.
heroes because they sold Russia to the West. putin brought strength to the Russians.

I recently had the opportunity to fly first class for the first time. Unlike in coach where there are maybe a couple of offenders, nobody in First turned anything off. They hid their phones in their pockets when the flight attendant walked by, but as soon as she was gone it was a sea of iPads. And all closer to the navigational equipment than coach. We did not crash. Either enforce the rule as a safety thing and have penalties for noncompliance or scrap it. When you have a policy that you don't enforce, people assume all policies are crap.

Note to FAA: I have no evidence that live passengers cause planes to crash. But perhaps in the interest of safety in case of any unknown effects, henceforth, only non-live passengers should be allowed to fly on airplanes. Additionally, they should be dressed only in their underwear so there is no hidden contraband brought aboard the plane. For similar reasons these rules should apply to the flight crew.

Can you blame employees for wanting to ask?  I mean when you read of the CEOs who have made millions more (like doubled their take home) when at the same time they ask the rank and file to take a pay cut and a even some furlough time?  Hmmm.  How can the rank and file really buy their arguments when the top brass just rakes it in and don't feel one bit guilty about it.  Yes and even top performers get screwed here too.  Then companies wonder why their retention rate is so poor.

I am one of those who would be affected by a financial transaction fee. However, I only pay $8,95 a trade, and try to trade in 100 share lots. So I pay about $0.09 a share. If I buy or sell more the cost per share is less. So a small fee of a few cents would not affect my trading. If I were to use a major brokerage my fees would run 3% or better, and that is why I use a discount broker.

There can be no doubt the government needs to raise revenue, no matter how much it can reduce spending. And keep in mind, when the government reduces spending, it as a ripple effect. Those anti tax people who advocate cutting government expenditures as they do, do not seem to be able to project the long term costs. In order to continue to cuit government spending over the long run, that would entail cutting government wages, and employees. Well we have already seen what happens when jobs are lost, and wages are brought down It is called deflation, and we are presently experiencing it.

America was found on the principle of equality, and one of those equalities was equality of citizenship. The framers of the constitution tried to prevent the establishment of royalty and inheritance of privilege. One of the motivating forces behind the estate tax was to keep some individuals from becoming just like royalty. You say someone has earned their wealth and should be allowed to keep it, but without limits, that wealth becomes greater and greater with each succeeding generation. They may not have titles, but they are still Dukes and Barons, with power that the ordinary citizen can not match.

We saw this all during the 20th century in South America. A few very rich, and a great many poor. It lead to Maoist revolutions. It is still being felt today, but we see countries like Brazil and Peru becoming economic leaders. It took egalitarian reform, and it is working. We can see by the example of Venezuela what happens when the wealthy accumulate all the wealth.

MEK, PMOI, the Mujahedeen e-Khalq, or People’s Mujahedeen, whatever you call them ARE NOW nothing but a cult. They are now nothing like what their founders set out to accomplish.  Because of their active assistance to Saddam Hussein during the Iraq-Iran war, the Iranian people will never accept MEK back on their soil in any capacity preferring the brutal rule of the mullahs than following the MEK.  As an ex-member of that organization all the way back to 30 years ago, the US government would do its image a lot of good by closing Camp Ashraf in Iraq, providing psychological assistance to its inhabitants, and distancing itself from MEK explicitly.

If the NBA wants to be nice to America, it shouldn't start the shortened season on Christmas Day. That is not a gift to families. Start the day before Christmas, December 24, and take Christmas Day off.
Big Al needs to Get Out of Denver.

"JPMorgan Chase is mostly financed with debt because, alone among modern executives, bankers do not believe in much equity financing for their businesses. So the financial losses to debt holders could be on the order of $1 trillion.”

This surely relates to the fact that creditors have been bailed out at par value for decades. Government policy seems strikingly targeted at encouraging debt and leverage through creditor bailouts and easy money.

My girlfriend and I were in Sarajevo at the time of this incident. In fact, we had just left the War Museum and were heading across the street towards the bus station to look over schedules, when the man, perhaps 50 yards away from us, began shooting. We ran off into a nearby shopping mall and observed the proceedings from there as the local police shot the man, who never sought cover, in the legs. I think for us, and virtually everyone there, the incident was surreal, and wholly unrelated to the pleasure of visiting Bosnia in general. The comparison of Sarajevo to NYC seems appropriate; we encountered nothing but sincere warmth on the part of everyone we met. We thoroughly enjoyed Croatia as well, but Sarajevo and Mostar occupy particularly special places in our hearts. We hope to return very soon. For anyone who espouses multi-culturalism, and I am one of them, the country strikes me as having undertaken the grandest of projects, and given what they endured so recently, they have succeeded phenomenally well in moving on towards an accepting and understanding society.

Hey, Putin, THIS Boo's for YOU!

BOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!

"For the growing chorus of observers who fear that a breakup of the euro zone might be at hand, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has a pointed rebuke: It’s never going to happen."

No person, including Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke, has more nervous investors hanging on every uttered word than does Angela Merkel. For her to say anything else than the above "pointed rebuke" would be a catastrophic catalyst of panic and flight from European Bonds. Therefore, the rebuke should be regarded as merely dutiful, and taken with a grain of salt.

The courage of the Euro elite will be measured by the decisiveness with which they amputate the financially gangrenous parts of the Euro zone in order to save what could potentially remain of the whole.
